pros:
Value innovation
Supportive manager
Care about staff wellbeing
cons: Don't always listen to staff voice regarding changes to processes within the organisation

job_title: Enabler in Rochester, South East England, England
pros: As the conditions are the same as those at the NHS, should be the best place to work in Community Care.
cons: Care Certificate, you are supposed to have 6 months to complete this, but I was given only part of it 3 months after I started, as I left as covid became an issue, I didn't actually complete due to issues over the 'Reflections', which hadn't been discussed at any point until they wanted me to complete the CC in my 6th and last month there.

review_title: Assess patient from hospital to rehabilitate them back home
pros: To rehabilitate and enable patient back into their own home.
cons: Patients being discharged to early from hospital and having to re admitted back into hospital

pros: Met some nice colleagues and employment was quick.
cons: Staff retention appears poor. No TOIL or additional pay offered when working over hours which everyone seemed to do (part of the culture). No discretion for a medical appointment, would be expected to take annual leave. Very little concern for staff health and wellbeing from management.

job_title: Disability Support Worker in Chatham, England
pros: Only work weekdays, bank holidays and public holidays off, good training opportunities

job_title: Registered Nurse in Rochester, South East England, England
pros:
The nursing teams are very good across the organisation
Overall managers are quite reasonable
Friendly corporate team
cons:
There is recently developing a blame culture - someone has to be blamed.
Threats of disciplinary action for sickness and other matters that don't warrant disciplinary action - staff just have to be listened to.
Certain high grade managers don't have a clue what they are talking about in relation to certain topics . 
In the corporate and higher management  team it is very much if your face fits

review_title: Lots of training and support,great culture...pay could be better
pros: There is a lot of support from your colleagues and team leaders ,, depends on who you work under.  There is enough work also for zero hours workers to do, although they are not flexible with working times.
cons:
Zero hours are treated like thrash. They don't give you sick pay etc irrespective of legislation which allows you equal compensation as contracted staff, if you work a certain number of hours on average. 

The work can get very busy, Mileage is paid at above 50p (taxed through  a reduction in ur allowance by HMRC) for the first 3000 miles which surprisingly goes really quickly as you do drive A LOT. Then it drops to 20p....

review_title: great place to work... highly recommend
pros: MCH is dynamic, agile and constantly changing for the better. Ideas are listened to and put in place quickly. Management are friendly and understand the pressures people are under. The main focus always remains the best interest of the patients. If you want to work for a modern NHS organisation, MCH is for you. If you're a tradition NHS long winded, long meetings, can't make a decision unless 10,000 clinicians are consulted then move on....
cons: Not enough money from the commissioners. We could achieve so much more!

job_title: H R Administrator in Rochester, South East England, England
pros: i have worked for MCH for nearly 10 years, i have always found them to be a fair organisation to work for, they follow their values and promote learning.  I find them flexible when needed.  I have worked for many NHS organisations over the years and I think its fair to say that being a social enterprise gives MCH a family feel, they hold events throughout the year for all staff to attend regardless of position.  on the hole I think they are really inclusive.
cons: Parking can sometimes be an issue, but most places don't provide parking anyway so even that is a pro

pros: Supportive, friendly and welcoming.  You feel like you are part of a family.  The organisation engages with staff and listens to their views.  I have been supported well and had plenty of opportunities to develop and progress.  I feel valued and recognised for the work I do.
cons: Pressures on staff which are sometimes beyond the organisations control.  Being a community provider means we have less control of things that are really important to staff e.g. buildings and issues take longer to resolve.

pros: Great teams with fabulous staff, who are caring and creative and work hard to the best job they can do, despite the challenges the NHS brings today. Both corporate and clinical services maintain a focus on what's best for patients. Team members peers and senior managers are supportive and recognise the challenges for staff and support a open and transparent culture a genuine good place to work.
cons: Are beyond organisational control ,increasing demands on services from a growing ageing population with finite resources.

review_title: Former NHS organisation struggling to change.
pros:
Some very dedicated staff who are great to work with.
Good benefits and holidays.
cons:
Micro-managing by executive management team, rather than allowing the specialists to do their job.
Constant restructures.
Unfair distribution of training budgets.
Not many opportunities for career progression.

review_title: Ineffective Leaders with no understanding of direction or personnel
job_title: Clinical Staff in Rochester, South East England, England
pros: Lovely clients and co workers.  Staff with great ideas and lots of energy despite managements' best efforts to undermine them and/or take credit for their ideas.
cons: No joined up picture of what the service could be. Mundane, boring leadership, very poor support or staff development.  Large caseloads.

pros: Caring and understanding, dynamic and new ways of working, benefits and good annual leave. A team focused organisation that will give the support that you need when you need it.
cons: Due to the nature of healthcare in general, the pace of change is very fast but always for the better.

pros: Working with Dementia is extremely rewarding, it allows you to connect with families on a personal level.
cons: N/A One of the best companies I have worked for.

pros: Supportive on some aspects, check up on you
cons: Unsupportive on others, Sickness policy is dyer
